subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE IS NOW LIVE FOR TODAY'S SESSION
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include Australia Trade Balance and Fed's Williams speech
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump meeting with Chinese President Xi to sign a trade deal could be delayed until December as discussions over terms and venue continue, while it is still possible a deal may not be reached although a deal is more likely than not according to a US official. The official added that China pushing for more tariff rollbacks is not seen as derailing the progress and that Europe is seen as a likely venue for a Trump-Xi meeting with Switzerland and Sweden among possible choices, while Iowa is not likely. There were also comments from a senior US administration official that the US is mulling a Trump-Xi meeting to sign an interim trade deal after the NATO summit in London in early December, but no decision has been made yet. (Newswires)

US has asked for Chinese President Xi Jinping's travel schedule to see where and when a possible phase one trade deal could be signed, according to FBN's Lawrence citing a trade source. (Twitter)

China are reportedly to set up a punitive compensation system for intellectual property infringement, while it is said to deepen medium and small lender reform along with improving their governance and internal risk control. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

EU Trade Commissioner Malmstrom said the US is still not ready for talks on industry duty reactions and that the EU still faces threat of US auto tariffs, while she reiterated that the EU would retaliate against any US tariffs. (Newswires)

  • EU Markit Services Final PMI (Oct) 52.2 vs. Exp. 51.8 (Prev. 51.8). (Newswires)
  • EU Markit Composite Final PMI (Oct) 50.6 vs. Exp. 50.2 (Prev. 50.2)
  • EU Retail Sales MM (Sep) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.3%, Rev. 0.6%)
  • EU Retail Sales YY (Sep) 3.1% vs. Exp. 2.5% (Prev. 2.1%, Rev. 2.7%)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 7.929M vs. Exp. 1.515M (Prev. 5.702M). (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia is set to press OPEC members for production cuts ahead of its Aramco IPO according to reports citing sources, while the Saudis are said to want the cartel’s "laggards" to comply with current curbs rather than pushing for deeper trims in output. In related news, other source reports also noted the largest OPEC+ producers are not pushing for deeper oil cuts. (WSJ/Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea called upcoming US military exercises extremely provocative and a dangerous act, while it added that dialogue with the US is on the verge of extinction, according to BNO News. (Twitter)

Iranian President Rouhani said the nuclear site Fordow will soon be back to full production and there were separate reports that Iran briefly detained an IAEA inspector and seized her travel documents. (Newswires/Twitter)

Turkish officials said President Erdogan and US President Trump spoke on the phone and reconfirmed they will meet in Washington on November 13th. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed's Evans (voter, dove) said the US economy and monetary policy is in a good place and he will be keeping an eye on inflation in deciding future policy. Evans also stated that we have accomplished accommodative policy with the 3rd rate cut and policy is not that far off neutral, while he added that inflation has been on the light side and that it is important to be clear on what it means by symmetry to the 2% inflation target. (Newswires)

Fed's Williams (voter, neutral) said the labour market is really strong and has low unemployment, while he added officials have lowered their view of what sustainable level of unemployment is based on low inflation and inflation pressures are very muted today. Williams also stated that monetary policy is moderately accommodative right now and the Fed will be data dependent as well as preemptive going forward, while he also suggested that in the event of a recession, he would address it by putting interest rates to zero, using communication and through asset purchases. (Newswires)

  • US Labor Costs (Q3 P) 3.6% vs. Exp. 2.2% (Prev. 2.6%, Rev. 2.4%). (Newswires)
  • US Productivity (Q3 P) -0.3% vs. Exp. 0.9% (Prev. 2.3%, Rev. 2.5%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Xerox (XRX) and HP Inc. (HPQ) traded in the green after XRX mulls a cash and stock offer for HPQ; CNBC’s Faber citing sources said the offer will likely be a real premium, cash and stock offer, with synergies approaching USD 3bln. Papa John’s (PZZA) traded higher after it announced a more streamlined senior management structure, and backed its current guidance, but It slightly improved its SSS guidance. Uber (UBER) hit a new low after its lockup on shares expired today, allowing insiders to sell their shares for the first times, according to CNBC. Also, an Uber block trade is said to price 2mln shares at USD 26.90/shr, it initially opened as low as 8% although pared back half its losses throughout the session. YUM Brands (YUM) benefitted from unconfirmed source reports that Bill Ackman was building a large stake in YUM. Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) pared back some of its gains yesterday after reports suggested it is in talks with advisers about going private. Tifany & Co (TIF) asked LVMH (MC FP) to raise its USD 14.5bln offer, saying the USD 120/shr offer significantly undervalues the company. S&P 500 0.1% at 3077, NASDAQ-100 -0.2% at 8196, Dow Jones 0% at 27492.

After this week’s sharp rise in yields, the Treasury curve bull-flattened on Wednesday, though major spreads only narrowed modestly. An early dip after better than expected Germany factory orders was short-lived, and the complex continued to rally amid caution on US/China trade talks, where there are still some concerns that the deal might fall apart. A solid 10-year auction added to the rally, after the sale stopped through the screens by 1bps (recently, the auctions have tailed frequently), with cover above recent averages, and indirect bidder participation picking up – the well-received auction reveals that there is still demand for medium-dated US paper, and as such, providing validation to the analysts who have this week talked about how the complex has run out of fresh reasons for yields to continue rising; this view was encapsulated by a hefty trade in the TYZ9 131-00 strike (which analysts said looks for an implied 10-year yield of 1.6% vs the current 1.82%), where paper paid 3 ticks 100k times (50k on the screens, 50k blocked). Tomorrow’s 30-year auction will be viewed in a similar light by macro players looking to judge whether we have indeed reached a short/medium-term bottom, or whether there is demand for long-dated paper at these levels. SocGen's analysts say the 30-year sector looks fair in asset swap, observing that the current WI trades above the previous auction's stop-out rate, indicating relative cheapness versus the previous auction cycle. The last auction saw robust demand from foreigners and investment funds and was digested well considering it resulted in the lowest stop-out yield on record. With that said, SocGen says that the previous auction failed to break the streak of recent tails at 30-year auctions, tailing for the fifth time in six months. SocGen holds a neutral bias into Thursday's sale. T-note futures (Z9) settled up 13 ticks129.10+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 6th November 2019: Trump/Xi meeting might be delayed until December
content:
US MARKET WRAP 6th November 2019: Trump/Xi meeting might be delayed until December

  • * SNAPSHOT: Equities flat/lower; Treasuries up; Dollar flat; Crude down.
  • * REAR VIEW: Trump/Xi meeting might be delayed to December; Saudis pressing for deeper deeper supply cuts; US productivity fell in Q3; Brazil TOR auction raises fewer funds than anticipated.
  • * COMING-UP: Data: Australian Trade Balance Goods & Services, German Industrial Output and Construction PMI, US Initial Jobless Claims. Events: BoE Rate Decision & Press Conference. Speakers: BoE’s Carney (Press Conference), Fed’s Kaplan, ECB’s Lagarde. Supply: US and France. Earnings: Walt Disney, Booking Holdings, Zoetis, Activision Blizzard, Monster Beverage, Siemens, Deutsche Telekom, Zurich Insurance, Generali, UniCredit, ArcelorMittal.

* US/CHINA TRADE: The President Trump-Xi meeting to sign a trade deal could be delayed until December as discussions over terms and venue continue, according to Reuters citing a US official (seeing US equities dip lower); the source said that it was still possible a deal may not be reached, but it was more likely to be reached than not. The official went on to say that Europe is seen as a likely venue, with Switzerland and Sweden among possible choices, but Iowa is not likely. China pushing for more tariff rollbacks is not seen as derailing the progress, the official added, who believes China sees a quick trade deal as the best chance for favourable terms given Trump's electoral and impeachment pressures. Later reports also suggested the Trump/Xi signing could take place around the time of the NATO summit in London on 3-4th December. Additionally, a trade source told Fox that the White House had requested Xi’s travel schedule to see where and when the deal could be signed.

* FED: Fed's Evans (Dovish, Voter) said the Fed has accomplished accommodative policy with its third rate cut in 2019, adding that he believed policy was now not that far off neutral, and reiterated an argument heard from many Fed officials that the US economy and monetary policy was in a good place. Looking ahead, Evans said he will be keeping an eye on inflation in deciding future policy, stating that inflation has been on the light side, and it was important to be clear on what it means by 'symmetry' to its 2% inflation target. On the Fed's repo operations, Evans said there are operational issues in setting up a repo facility, though the Fed balance sheet operations should address many of the repo issues. Fed's Williams (voter, neutral) said the labour market was really strong, noting the low unemployment rate; officials have lowered their view of what sustainable level of unemployment is based on low inflation, inflation pressures are very muted. Williams argued that monetary policy was moderately accommodative at the moment, adding that slowing global growth and muted inflation pressures argue for a more accommodative policy (it was unclear whether Williams was referring to this year's rate cuts or future policy, although comments from other Fed members have supported the former). Looking ahead, Williams said the Fed will be data dependent and pre-emptive going forward.

* US PRODUCTIVITY/LABOUR COSTS: US productivity fell 0.3% Q/Q in Q3, against an expected rise of 0.9%; Labour costs rose 3.6% against an expected rise of 2.2%. The productivity decline was the first since Q4 2015, and as a result, annual productivity growth slowed to a pace of 1.4% Y/Y, the lowest rate of growth since late 2018. Unit labour costs rose, lifting the annual pace of labour cost growth to 3.1%, the quickest in more than 5 years. Oxford Economics said that, amid a tight labour market, labour cost pressures are continuing to build just as productivity is reverting to its subdued structural trend: "Given slower domestic and foreign economic momentum and limited companies' pricing power, tighter profit margins will continue to remain a key headwind for business activity as we head into in 2020."

* GEOPOLITICS: Iran previously announced it has begun enriching uranium by 5% at its Fordow plant, with the region noting it has the potential to increase it to 20% if needed. Today, Iranian President Rouhani stated the Fordow site will “soon be back to full production” as it further scaled back its commitments to the 2015 nuclear accord. Russia’s Foreign minister Lavrov responded to the moves, stating Iran should commit to the 2015 nuclear pact, although it does understand why it is reducing its commitments.

* NZ Q3 JOBS DATA: Data overnight showed the jobless rate rising by more than anticipated in Q3, reversing the unexpected flat in Q2. However, UBS noted that despite the lift in unemployment, the labour market remains tight, as evidenced by falling underutilisation and rising wage pressures. Thus, based on the current state of the labour market, further monetary policy stimulus seems unwarranted. With that said, UBS argues that the near-term outlook for the labour market does not look so bright, and expects the RBNZ to downgrade its growth outlook next week, which will likely be accompanied by softer near-term labour market prospects; the bank looks for the RBNZ to cut its OCR by 25bps at the 13th November confab.

* CANADIAN IVEY PMI: for the month of October came in soft at 51.8, lower than the prior months 55.8. The seasonally adjusted reading, however, showed less of a deterioration, slipping to 48.2 in October from 48.7 in September.

* EZ BANKING UNION PROPOSALS: German Finance Minister Scholz presented proposals for completing the EU-wide banking union. The proposals show the Finance Minister is mulling a deposit insurance mechanism to protect deposits over EUR 100k - something which Germany has pushed-back on in the past. "Germany has traditionally been reluctant to introduce a common deposit insurance system across the eurozone," Stratfor writes, "however, the plan still stipulates that national insurance schemes must be the first to react in the event of a banking crisis and demands structural reforms in the Eurozone before introducing the deposit insurance." Stratfor also notes that the proposals also include some potentially controversial suggestions, such as ending protections for senior bondholders of failed banks, as well as harmonising tax systems across the Eurozone, which the consultancy says might complicate Berlin's efforts to impose its own version of a banking union.

* BRAZIL TOR AUCTION: The auction of oil drilling rights raised USD 17.3bln, short of the expected USD 26.5bln, which analysts said would have offered Brazil's public finances with some needed breathing room. The USDBRL rose sharply in wake of the auction, with traders suggesting that the lack of competition (for instance, state firm Petrobras took 90% of the Buzios consortium; Sepia and Atapu oil blocks received no bids, while some rights were unsold) and missing the estimate of funds raised was a negative. FX strategists have noted that by Petrobras winning much of what was offered mitigates the possibility of inflows into Brazil, which are likely to occur in December.

* WTI (Z9) SETTLED USD 0.88 LOWER AT USD 56.35/BBL; BRENT (Z9) SETTLED USD 1.22 LOWER AT USD 61.74/BBL: Crude futures sold off as risk appetite cooled from somewhat exuberant levels seen at the beginning of the week, on top of the bearish inventory report. The benchmarks were firmer in the earlier session before reversing course as major equity bourses were offered on the US cash equity open. The EIA reported crude stocks building 7.9mln bbls, larger than both expected and API figure, whilst US production remained unchanged at the record level of 12.6mln BPD; both the products printed draws, with the gasoline larger than expected, whilst the distillates figure was slightly lighter than expected. Refinery utilisation declining larger than expected and a chunky 1.7mln bbl build at Cushing didn’t provide much support either. Not long after the EIAs, it was reported that the largest OPEC+ producers are not pushing for deeper oil cuts, which followed from an earlier WSJ article that suggested Saudi would be pressing other members for cuts via further compliance with existing agreements, and that key member Russia had informed the group it wanted to just maintain the current agreement. Canadian grade crudes (WCS) remain under pressure amid the Keystone pipeline shutdown, where operator TC Energy has reportedly ordered a force majeure.

* T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED at. After this week’s sharp rise in yields, the Treasury curve bull-flattened on Wednesday, though major spreads only narrowed modestly. An early dip after better than expected Germany factory orders was short-lived, and the complex continued to rally amid caution on US/China trade talks, where there are still some concerns that the deal might fall apart. A solid 10-year auction added to the rally, after the sale stopped through the screens by 1bps (recently, the auctions have tailed frequently), with cover above recent averages, and indirect bidder participation picking up – the well-received auction reveals that there is still demand for medium-dated US paper, and as such, providing validation to the analysts who have this week talked about how the complex has run out of fresh reasons for yields to continue rising; this view was encapsulated by a hefty trade in the TYZ9 131-00 strike (which analysts said looks for an implied 10-year yield of 1.6% vs the current 1.82%), where paper paid 3 ticks 100k times (50k on the screens, 50k blocked). Tomorrow’s 30-year auction will be viewed in a similar light by macro players looking to judge whether we have indeed reached a short/medium-term bottom, or whether there is demand for long-dated paper at these levels. SocGen's analysts say the 30-year sector looks fair in asset swap, observing that the current WI trades above the previous auction's stop-out rate, indicating relative cheapness versus the previous auction cycle. The last auction saw robust demand from foreigners and investment funds and was digested well considering it resulted in the lowest stop-out yield on record. With that said, SocGen says that the previous auction failed to break the streak of recent tails at 30-year auctions, tailing for the fifth time in six months. SocGen holds a neutral bias into Thursday's sale.

* S&P 500 0.1% at 3077, NASDAQ-100 -0.2% at 8196, Dow Jones  0% at 27492; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  0.1%, Consumer Staples  0.5%, Energy  -2.3%, Financials  0.4%, Health Care  0.6%, Industrials  0%, Information Technology  0%, Materials  -0.1%, Telecommunication Services  -0.2%, Utilities  0.3%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Xerox (XRX) and HP Inc. (HPQ) traded in the green after XRX mulls a cash and stock offer for HPQ; CNBC’s Faber citing sources said the offer will likely be a real premium, cash and stock offer, with synergies approaching USD 3bln. Papa John’s (PZZA) traded higher after it announced a more streamlined senior management structure, and backed its current guidance, but It slightly improved its SSS guidance. Uber (UBER) hit a new low after its lockup on shares expired today, allowing insiders to sell their shares for the first times, according to CNBC. Also, an Uber block trade is said to price 2mln shares at USD 26.90/shr, it initially opened as low as 8% although pared back half its losses throughout the session. YUM Brands (YUM) benefitted from unconfirmed source reports that Bill Ackman was building a large stake in YUM. Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) pared back some of its gains yesterday after reports suggested it is in talks with advisers about going private. Tifany & Co (TIF) asked LVMH (MC FP) to raise its USD 14.5bln offer, saying the USD 120/shr offer significantly undervalues the company.

* EARNINGS: Altice (ATUS) fell 20% after poor earnings, missing on EPS and revenue, and lowered its FY revenue guidance. Diamondback Energy (FANG) fell ~15% after poor earnings, which missed on EPS and revenue. DaVita (DVA) among outperformers as it reported top and bottom line beats, and also raised its FY20 adj. EPS forecasts whilst re-affirming its CapEx view. CVS (CVS) also performed well as it reported a beat on revenue and provided EPS guidance for FY19 above expectations, whilst also raising its revenue forecast. Coty (COTY) and Humana (COTY) also higher on earnings.

* FX WRAP: Negative US/China trade headlines, which suggested Novembers Phase One deal signing summit could be delayed to December, saw safe havens JPY and Gold catch a bid; USDJPY fell to lows of 108.84 from above 109.00, while Gold moved to highs of USD 1494/oz. Meanwhile, risk sensitive currencies took a hit; AUD and NZD fell to session lows of 0.6877 and 0.6360 respectively, with the Aussie bouncing off of resistance at this level (Monday’s low). CAD was also hit, but had already been heading lower alongside falling crude prices and weak Ivey PMI data. USD and EUR were unconcerned by trade headlines, finishing the session flat; relatively directionless trade which saw EURUSD range between 1.1060 and 1.1090; USDCNH, however, moved back above 7.00. GBP was slightly weaker; as the Conservatives launched its election campaign. Elsewhere in EMFX; BRL was whacked for its own reasons, USDBRL rose above 4.0800 from below 4.000 after Brazil’s TOR mine auction raised less money than hoped. ZAR meanwhile was hit on further Eskom power supply concerns.

subject: PREVIEW: US to sell USD 27bln of 10-year notes on 6th November 2019 at 1800 GMT/1300 ET
content:
THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will auction USD 84bln in a new 3-year (USD 38bln, Tuesday), a new 10-year (USD 27bln, Wednesday) and a new 30-year (USD 19bln, Thursday). According to UBS, at next week's mid-month settlement, around USD 89bln of cash flows come due (excluding SOMA holdings, but including around USD 61bln of redemptions and around USD 28bln of coupons will fall due). 

10-YEAR PREVIEW: From a relative value perspective, the 10-year sector has some slight set up ahead of Wednesday's auction, analysts said, and it trades marginally cheap in asset swap as well as on the curve against 5s and 30s. SocGen also feels that it looks cheap on an outright basis, and notes that the current 10-year yield is trading above the stop-out rates for all of the last three auctions. SocGen observes that, since the last auction cycle, 2s10s curve has steepened, emphasising the relative cheapness of the sector. Additionally, SocGen points out that the current 10 is trading special in repo, which indicates stronger demand for the issue. With that said, dealer holdings in the 7-11 year bucket are relatively high, SocGen says, and with the recent run of tails, could adversely impact demand at the sale. 

10-YEAR AUCTION RECENT HISTORY:

Daily FX Wrap: Usd/G10s remain rangebound, but Real and Rand reeling
content:
DXY

The index is still hovering in a tight range just below 98.000 after running out of impetus on Tuesday and into a Fib retracement level just above the post-Fed peak and is now testing chart support around the 21 DMA (97.840 between 97.975-775 parameters). In contrast to yesterday’s bullish non-manufacturing ISM, the Greenback failed to glean any momentum from mixed US Q3 productivity and labour cost data or Fed commentary via Evans and Williams, but did lose traction against the backdrop of retreating UST yields and curve re-flattening. Ahead, 10 year supply and Fed’s Harker.

JPY/EUR/NZD/CHF/AUD

The major ‘outperformers’, but within narrow bands vs the Greenback around 109.00, just below 1.1100 and sub-0.6400 respectively. The Yen continues to feel the weight of risk-on flows due to US-China Phase 1 trade pact expectations, but managed to stem the tide ahead of recent lows and a Fib, while the single currency derived a degree of support from mostly firmer Eurozone services PMIs instead of a significant beat in German factory orders after testing chart support at 1.1064 in the form of a Fib. Note, however, Eur/Usd pulled up just shy of the 21 DMA (1.1095), and the Kiwi also stalled on the back of a mildly disappointing NZ Q3 labour report ahead of next week’s RBNZ policy meeting. Elsewhere, the Franc has regrouped alongside fellow safe-havens like the Jpy and Xau, with Usd/Chf drifting a bit further towards 0.9900 from 0.9940 and Eur/Chf back under 1.1000 compared to 1.1035 at one stage on Monday. Back down under, the Aussie is still battling to retain hold of the 0.6900 handle and sustain rallies beyond the round number round number or build on recent gains relative to its Antipodean counterpart as the Aud/Nzd cross slips back from circa 1.0830 to revisit 1.0800.

GBP/CAD/SEK/NOK

Sterling remains subject and hostage to breaking news and headlines related to the upcoming UK election and Brexit in the main, with Cable capped below 1.2900 and Eur/Gbp straddling 0.8600, but the Loonie handed back more gains vs it US rival after Canadian Ivey PMIs revealing a drop in the NSA gauge closer to 50.0 and deeper contractionary SA reading. Usd/Cad is nudging nearer 1.3200 in stark contrast to Eur/Sek and Eur/Nok that are both retesting technical support amidst reports of HFs taking profit on long positions or simply looking for more of a bullish cross/bearish Scandi Crown correction.

EM 

Some relief for the Rand or at least a diversion from Eskom-related underperformance as the Real became the regional whipping boy in wake of Brazil’s TOR mine raffle that raised less than anticipated or the authorities were hoping for, and aroused far fewer bidders than predicted. In short, 2 of the 4 blocks received no interest at all and the largest only 2 foreign bids to contest Petrobras that already has a 90% stake, resulting in Usd17.3 bn revenue vs Usd26.5 bn projected. Usd/Brl off highs, but still firmly above 4.0000 and towards the top of a 4.0875-3.9760 band.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: UST bid strengthens and spreads, leaving Dollar deflated
content: Big bullish block trades in futures and options, including a particularly aggressive call buyer in 10 year notes at the OTM 131.00 strike, have contributed to extended recovery gains in US Treasuries and curve re-flattening. Moreover, the enhanced retracement has prompted fresh Liffe peaks in Gilts, at 131.49 (+17 ticks), and even permeated previously detached or indifferent Bunds that recently rebounded through parity to 170.65 (+12 ticks). Conversely, lower yields and less steepening coupled with several existing external negative impulses have kept the Buck on the backfoot with the DXY hovering between 97.975-775 parameters and testing the 21 DMA.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 6th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Major European bourses are little changed thus far, in a relatively quiet EU session
  • Chinese President Xi's visit to Brazil next week may be too soon to sign a Phase One trade deal with the US., SCMP
  • Iranian President Rouhani says nuclear site Fordow will "soon be back to full production"; follows reports that they have begun injecting gas into the facility
  • FX complex is uninspiring with the USD marginally softer overall, debt
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US Labour Costs, Productivity and DoEs, Canadian Ivey PMI, ECB’s Holzmann, Fed’s Evans, Williams and Harker, supply from the US
  • Earnings: Qualcomm, CVS Health Corp, Fiserv, EOG Resource, Humana, Baidu, WEC Energy

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded lacklustre following a flat finish on Wall St where the major indices remained near record highs on US-China trade optimism, but with some caution seeping through amid Chinese demands for the removal of tariffs which is seen as a sticking point for the 'phase one' deal. ASX 200 (-0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) were mixed with underperformance in Australia’s gold miners after the precious metal slipped below the psychological key USD 1500/oz level, while trade in Tokyo was stable amid a mixed currency and as the local benchmark took a breather from the prior day’s surge to a fresh yearly high. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) were tentative after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and as participants await the next developments in the trade saga such including whether the US succumbs to China’s demands to roll-back tariffs. Finally, 10yr JGBs declined significantly overnight as the benchmark 10yr JGB yield rose to its highest in around 5 months, while the pressure in JGBs was later exacerbated following mixed 10yr auction results and after prices collapsed through a key support area around 153.60 which previously held up during the last 3 months.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0080 vs. Exp. 7.0090 (Prev. 7.0385)

BoJ minutes from September meeting stated it is appropriate to persistently continue with powerful easing and that Japan's economy had been on a moderate expanding trend although exports, production and business sentiment have been impacted by overseas slowdown. Furthermore, most members shared the view that it was becoming increasingly necessary to pay closer attention to chance momentum to reaching price target would be lost, while some members stated comprehensive examination needed on possibility financial institutions profits could decline further and that more banks could take excessive risks due to low rate environment. (Newswires)

China has signed contracts worth USD 15bln during visit from French President Macron, according to a Chinese government official - France says it has received approval for 20 French companies to export beef, poultry and port to China. (Newswires)

 

US

Chinese President Xi's visit to Brazil next week may be too soon to sign a Phase One trade deal with the US., SCMP citing sources, as the two sides are yet to reach a consensus, sources note time is very limited to finalise the details in writing for next week; Source notes that one idea was for a meeting in the US, but China disagreed. (SCMP)

Fed's Kashkari (2020 voter, Dove) said US interest rates are now modestly accommodative and stated the US economy is not at full employment yet. (Newswires)

Democrats have won both chambers of the Virginia General Assembly from the Republicans which previously had a 1-seat majority in both the state Senate and House of Delegates. In related news, Democrat candidate Beshear defeated Republican and incumbent Bevin in the Kentucky Gubernatorial Election, while Republican Lieutenant Governor Reeves won the election in Mississippi in what was a fairly tight race against Democrat Attorney General Hood. (Newswires)

Chinese and US defence chiefs are undergoing talks which are designed to improve cooperation and avoid "mishaps" between the two militaries, according to SCMP citing sources. (SCMP)

In response to the resumption of Canadian pork and beef imports by China, Chinese FM states the onus in relations is on Canada and they immediately demand the release of Huawei CFO Meng., Global Times. (Twitter)

EQUITIES

Major European bourses (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%) are choppy with the indices off having pared earlier upside amid cautious sentiment on multiple reports corroborating the narrative that China will push for further US tariff concessions before it signs off on a Phase 1 trade deal. Earlier in the session, the DAX and Euro Stoxx indices managed to again eke out fresh YTDs highs; the former was halted by resistance at 13170 (15th June 2018 high), ahead of further resistance at the 13200 level (22 May 2018 high). US equity futures are relatively flat intra-day and are yet to fully recover from Monday’s modest losses, which saw the contracts pull back slightly from YTD highs. “The tape is overbought, buyers seem “tired”, valuations are stretched, and trade expectations are elevated (the removal of the 9/1 tariffs is quietly becoming consensus thinking)” JPM noted yesterday, and “that this is making buyers reticent to aggressively chase at present levels.” The FTSE 100 underperforms amid weakness in large cap stocks. Sectors are mostly in the red, barring Consumer Staples (+1.0%) and Financials (+0.5%), with the latter supported by the continued rise in yield, which is also supporting SocGen (+5.3%) despite the firm reporting a net decline of 34.8% YY and a 20% drop in equities trading revenue in Q3. Co. CEO noted that the bank “delivered resilient net income in an unfavourable environment without yet benefitting from the positive effects of ongoing restructuring which is ahead of its 2020 objectives.” Sticking with earnings, solid numbers from Marks & Spencer (+2.1%) and Alstom (+3.8%) saw their respective shares moved higher. Conversely, weaker than forecast earnings from Wirecard (-1.1%), Dialog Semiconductors (-8.8%) and Adidas (-3.2%) sees their shares under pressure. Meanwhile, BT (-3.5%) have been hit by reports that Virgin Media dealt the company a “blow” by striking a deal to switch its 3mln mobile phone customers from the BT over to Vodaphone. Finally, Fincantieri (-1.6%) shares initially slumped amid reports that the Italian finance police are undertaking searches 19 shipbuilding companies working with the Co.

Softbank (9984 JT) 6M net profit -49.8% YY to JPY 421.55bln, Operating loss JPY 15.55bln vs. Prev. profit JPY 1.42tln, Pretax profit -20.3% YY to JPY 1.12tln. Co. sees JPY 497.7bln one-off loss on fair value of WeWork. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

Officials in Downing Street are reportedly divided over whether or not to include “no deal” in their party manifesto ahead of the upcoming election. (Telegraph)

Brexit Party leader Farage is reportedly in discussions with certain Eurosceptic Conservative candidates over withdrawing rival Brexit Party candidates at the upcoming general election after PM Johnson refused his nationwide pact. (Telegraph)

UK PM Johnson spoke with US President Trump today in which he asked him to remove tariffs on UK goods including scotch whisky and urged him to refrain from imposing tariffs on autos. (Newswires)

EU Markit Services Final PMI (Oct) 52.2 vs. Exp. 51.8 (Prev. 51.8); Composite Final PMI (Oct) 50.6 vs. Exp. 50.2 (Prev. 50.2)

- IHS Markit states, While the October PMI is consistent with quarterly GDP rising by 0.1%, the forward looking data points to a possible decline in economic output in the fourth quarter

German Markit Services PMI (Oct) 51.6 vs. Exp. 51.2 (Prev. 51.2); Composite Final PMI (Oct) 48.9 vs. Exp. 48.6 (Prev. 48.6)

- IHS notes, "Based on these figures, the German economy looks set for another weak performance in the fourth quarter, with a further mild contraction in output not out of the question."

 

FX

USD - The Dollar has lost some of its post-US services ISM vigour after the DXY managed to scale 98.000 and match the knee-jerk high notched in wake of last week’s FOMC policy meeting precisely. The index topped out just ahead of Fib resistance at 98.085, but also amidst broad consolidation in rival G10 currencies and especially safer-havens that have been underperforming on the positive US-China Phase 1 trade vibe alongside encouraging developments on proposed US auto tariffs. The DXY has slipped back below the big figure, but is holding well above recent lows and 97.500.

JPY/EUR/AUD/NZD - All marginally firmer vs the Greenback, as the Yen contained losses beyond 109.00 to 109.25 and did not threaten technical support around 109.37, while the Euro also defended a key chart level and Fib retracement circa 1.1064 before regrouping with the aid of some decent German data and mostly encouraging Eurozone PMIs. Elsewhere, the Aussie has crept back up to 0.6900 as the Aud/Nzd cross attempts to form a base above 1.0800 and Kiwi labours just under 0.6400 following fractionally weaker than forecast NZ jobs data overnight.

GBP/CHF/CAD - The Pound, Franc and Loonie are struggling to take advantage of the Buck’s fade, with Cable unable to reclaim 1.2900, Usd/Chf still elevated on the 0.9900 handle and Usd/Cad pivoting 1.3150 after Tuesday’s somewhat contrasting Canadian compared to US trade balances (relative to consensus), and ahead of today’s Ivey PMIs.

EM - The Rand has retraced quite sharply from sub-14.7400 vs the Dollar to 14.8000+ on renewed Eskom strife as the company suffers more severe power supply issues and concedes that output will not meet demand even though certain generation sites have resumed production after maintenance. Investors also waiting on tenterhooks to hear from SA President Ramaphosa at a conference aimed at drumming up foreign funds.

Notable FX option expiries, NY Cut:

- EUR/USD: 1.1025 (1.8BLN), 1.1100 (350M), 1.1135-40 (500M), 1.1150-60 (1.3BLN)

- EUR/GBP: 0.8640-45 (600M), 0.8700 (300M)

- AUD/USD: 0.6825 (2.3BLN)

- USD/JPY: 108.00 (1.5BLN), 108.75-85 (1BLN), 108.90-109.00 (450M), 109.15-25 (800M)

New Zealand Employment Change (Q3) Q/Q 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.8%). (Newswires) New Zealand Unemployment Rate (Q3) 4.2% vs. Exp. 4.1% (Prev. 3.9%)

South Africa's Eskom states that the power system continues to be severely constrained this morning, unplanned breakdowns above 12k MW; while some generation units have returned from maintenance these are not sufficient for demand. (Newswires)

 

FIXED INCOME

Only marginal deviation outside prior ranges, as Gilts managed to trade flat at 131.32 (vs -27 ticks at worst) and Bunds slipped to a marginal new Eurex low at 170.22 (-31 ticks vs +3 ticks at one stage) before the former lost momentum and the latter found some underlying buying interest. However, both EU benchmarks are still lagging US Treasuries that seem content to sit off recent troughs and the curve unwind a degree of the marked re-steepening amidst a moderately softer Dollar, less US-China Phase 1 euphoria and awaiting more Fed speak along with the 2nd tranche of this week’s issuance.

 

COMMODITIES 

Crude markets are modestly softer but off intraday lows, with downside seen following last night’s larger than expected headline API stocks builds, with crude inventories rising by 4.26mln BDP (vs. Exp. +1.5mln), whilst the cautious tone around the market provides little by way of sentiment-driven upside. Both the WTI Dec’ 19 and Brent Jan’ 19 contracts sit above October’s USD 56.90/bbl and USD 62.30/bbl highs – greater expectations for a US/China Phase 1 trade deal breakthrough combined with a better backdrop of macro data (i.e. US jobs data last Friday) seemingly continue to provide a base for now. In terms of crude specific news flow, the WSJ reported that the Saudis are to set to press OPEC members for production cuts ahead of its Aramco IPO, although the push would be more aimed at "laggards" to comply with current curbs, rather than pushing for deeper trims in output, the article caveated. Quoting sources, the WSJ added that Russia had privately told the group it wants to maintain the current targets until March whilst noting that Saudi wants to refrain from taking a bulk of the cuts – in fitting with recent separate source reports. Further, the article noted that the oil giant’s growth assumptions, as well as the dividend it promises investors, are predicated on oil prices around USD 65/bbl, according to an investor document. Looking ahead on the docket, oil traders will be eyeing the EIA crude stocks release as a scheduled catalyst with headline crude expected to print a build of 1.5mln barrels. In terms of the metals; gold is staging a tepid recovery after yesterday’s slide, which saw the precious metal slip briefly beneath the USD 1480/oz mark. Copper, meanwhile, is subdued after pulling back somewhat from yesterday’s 4-month highs around of USD 2.716/lbs.

API Crude Inventories: +4.26mln vs. Exp. +1.5mln (Prev. +0.59mln). (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia set to press OPEC members for production cuts ahead of its Aramco IPO, reports the WSJ citing sources. (WSJ)

- The oil giant’s growth assumptions, as well as the dividend it promises investors, are predicated on oil prices around $65 per barrel, according to an investor document

- moreover, OPEC still needs to assess first-quarter oil demand, WSJ says quoting the same people. They added that Russia had privately told the group it wants to maintain the current targets until March.

Iranian President Rouhani says nuclear site Fordow will "soon be back to full production". (Twitter) Follows confirmation that they have begun injecting gas into the plant, via State TV. (Newswires)

Tankers have been blocked from entering the Iraqi Nassiriya oil refinery by local protesters, leading to a fuel shortage in the Dhi Qar Province, according to sources. (Newswires)

subject: Russia Foreign Minister Lavrov says Tehran should fulfill its commitments under the 2015 nuclear pact, though understands why it is reducing its commitments
Humana Inc (HUM) Q3 19 (USD): Adj EPS 5.03 (exp. 4.58), Revenue 16.24bln (exp. 16.14bln). FY EPS view 17.75 (exp. 17.64); sees FY individual Medicare Advantage memberships to grow to around 530k
CVS Health Corp (CVS) Q3 19 (USD): GAAP EPS 1.17 (exp. 1.77), Revenue 65.0bln (exp. 63.bln). FY EPS view  6.97-7.05 (exp. 6.98),
RANsquawk EU Mid Session: Tentative trade as markets tread water awaiting fresh catalysts - 6th November 2019

Investors also waiting on tenterhooks to hear from SA President Ramaphosa at a conference aimed at drumming up foreign funds.

FIXED INCOME

Only marginal deviation outside prior ranges, as Gilts managed to trade flat at 131.32 (vs -27 ticks at worst) and Bunds slipped to a marginal new Eurex low at 170.22 (-31 ticks vs +3 ticks at one stage) before the former lost momentum and the latter found some underlying buying interest. However, both EU benchmarks are still lagging US Treasuries that seem content to sit off recent troughs and the curve unwind a degree of the marked re-steepening amidst a moderately softer Dollar, less US-China Phase 1 euphoria and awaiting more Fed speak along with the 2nd tranche of this week’s issuance.

COMMODITIES                                      

Crude markets modestly softer but off intraday lows, with downside seen following last night’s larger than expected headline API stocks builds, with crude inventories rising by 4.26mln BDP (vs. Exp. +1.5mln), whilst the cautious tone around the market provides little by way of sentiment-driven upside. Both the WTI Dec’ 19 and Brent Jan’ 19 contracts sit above October’s USD 56.90/bbl and USD 62.30/bbl highs – greater expectations for a US/China Phase 1 trade deal breakthrough combined with a better backdrop of macro data (i.e. US jobs data last Friday) seemingly continue to provide a base for now. In terms of crude specific news flow, the WSJ reported that the Saudis are to set to press OPEC members for production cuts ahead of its Aramco IPO, although the push would be more aimed at "laggards" to comply with current curbs, rather than pushing for deeper trims in output, the article caveated. Quoting sources, the WSJ added that Russia had privately told the group it wants to maintain the current targets until March whilst noting that Saudi wants to refrain from taking a bulk of the cuts – in fitting with recent separate source reports. Further, the article noted that the oil giant’s growth assumptions, as well as the dividend it promises investors, are predicated on oil prices around USD 65/bbl, according to an investor document. Looking ahead on the docket, oil traders will be eyeing the EIA crude stocks release as a scheduled catalyst with headline crude expected to print a build of 1.5mln barrels. In terms of the metals; gold is staging a tepid recovery after yesterday’s slide, which saw the precious metal slip briefly beneath the USD 1480/oz mark. Copper, meanwhile, is subdued after pulling back somewhat from yesterday’s 4-month highs around of USD 2.716/lbs.

subject: FX Morning Colour: mixed and muted midweek moves for majors (thus far)
content:
USD

The Dollar has lost some of its post-US services ISM vigour after the DXY managed to scale 98.000 and match the knee-jerk high notched in wake of last week’s FOMC policy meeting precisely. The index topped out just ahead of Fib resistance at 98.085, but also amidst broad consolidation in rival G10 currencies and especially safer-havens that have been underperforming on the positive US-China Phase 1 trade vibe alongside encouraging developments on proposed US auto tariffs. The DXY has slipped back below the big figure, but is holding well above recent lows and 97.500.

JPY/EUR/AUD/NZD

All marginally firmer vs the Greenback, as the Yen contained losses beyond 109.00 to 109.25 and did not threaten technical support around 109.37, while the Euro also defended a key chart level and Fib retracement circa 1.1064 before regrouping with the aid of some decent German data and mostly encouraging Eurozone PMIs. Elsewhere, the Aussie has crept back up to 0.6900 as the Aud/Nzd cross attempts to form a base above 1.0800 and Kiwi labours just under 0.6400 following fractionally weaker than forecast NZ jobs data overnight.

GBP/CHF/CAD

The Pound, Franc and Loonie are struggling to take advantage of the Buck’s fade, with Cable unable to reclaim 1.2900, Usd/Chf still elevated on the 0.9900 handle and Usd/Cad pivoting 1.3150 after Tuesday’s somewhat contrasting Canadian compared to US trade balances (relative to consensus), and ahead of today’s Ivey PMIs.

EM

The Rand has retraced quite sharply from sub-14.7400 vs the Dollar to 14.8000+ on renewed Eskom strife as the company suffers more severe power supply issues and concedes that output will not meet demand even though certain generation sites have resumed production after maintenance. Investors also waiting on tenterhooks to hear from SA President Ramaphosa at a conference aimed at drumming up foreign funds.

Bunds: rather belated nod to upbeat German data
content: After the initial scant or fleeting reaction to significantly stronger than expected German factory orders, renewed selling in the core Eurozone bond nudged prices down through Tuesday’s Eurex session low and support ahead of the 170.00 level. Turnover has also picked up, but the 10 year debt future may find some underlying bids near the 170.27 base as the corresponding cash yield tests -30 bp and attention switches to the run of regional services PMIs, retail sales and several ECB speakers. However, Bunds are looking increasingly bearish from a technical perspective and given a more upbeat or less bleak fundamental backdrop, so rebounds may remain tame and short-lived.

content:

  • Asian equities traded lacklustre following a flat finish on Wall St where the major indices remained near record highs
  • Participants await the next developments in the trade saga and whether the US succumbs to China’s demands to roll-back tariffs
  • Brexit Party leader Farage is reportedly in discussions with certain Eurosceptic Conservatives over withdrawing rival Brexit Party candidates at the upcoming general election
  • DXY slightly eased back from the 98.00 level but held on to the majority of the spoils from this week’s rally
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ Services & Comp PMI and Retail Sales, US Labour Costs, Productivity and DoEs, Canadian Ivey PMI, ECB’s de Guindos, Mersch and Holzmann, Fed’s Evans, Williams and Harker, supply from the US
  • Earnings: Qualcomm, CVS Health Corp, Fiserv, EOG Resource, Humana, Baidu, WEC Energy, Adidas, BMW, Ahold Delhaize, SocGen, Sampo, Hannover Re, Wirecard, CRH Industrial, Dialog Semiconductor, Marks & Spencer

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded lacklustre following a flat finish on Wall St where the major indices remained near record highs on US-China trade optimism, but with some caution seeping through amid Chinese demands for the removal of tariffs which is seen as a sticking point for the 'phase one' deal. ASX 200 (-0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) were mixed with underperformance in Australia’s gold miners after the precious metal slipped below the psychological key USD 1500/oz level, while trade in Tokyo was stable amid a mixed currency and as the local benchmark took a breather from the prior day’s surge to a fresh yearly high. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) were tentative after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and as participants await the next developments in the trade saga such including whether the US succumbs to China’s demands to roll-back tariffs. Finally, 10yr JGBs declined significantly overnight as the benchmark 10yr JGB yield rose to its highest in around 5 months, while the pressure in JGBs was later exacerbated following mixed 10yr auction results and after prices collapsed through a key support area around 153.60 which previously held up during the last 3 months.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0080 vs. Exp. 7.0090 (Prev. 7.0385)

US Senate Finance Committee Director said the Phase One China trade deal will "possibly" be signed in Iowa. (FBN)

US imports of Chinese goods subject to tariffs fell by USD 35bln in H1 2019 according to a UN study, which stated that Taiwan, Mexico and the EU are main beneficiaries of the trade war, replacing some Chinese exports to the US. (Newswires)

BoJ minutes from September meeting stated it is appropriate to persistently continue with powerful easing and that Japan's economy had been on a moderate expanding trend although exports, production and business sentiment have been impacted by overseas slowdown. Furthermore, most members shared the view that it was becoming increasingly necessary to pay closer attention to chance momentum to reaching price target would be lost, while some members stated comprehensive examination needed on possibility financial institutions profits could decline further and that more banks could take excessive risks due to low rate environment. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Officials in Downing Street are reportedly divided over whether or not to include “no deal” in their party manifesto ahead of the upcoming election. (Teleggraph)

 

Brexit Party leader Farage is reportedly in discussions with certain Eurosceptic Conservative candidates over withdrawing rival Brexit Party candidates at the upcoming general election after PM Johnson refused his nationwide pact. (Telegraph)

 

UK PM Johnson spoke with US President Trump today in which he asked him to remove tariffs on UK goods including scotch whisky and urged him to refrain from imposing tariffs on autos. (Newswires) 

FX

DXY slightly eased back from the 98.00 level but held on to the majority of the spoils from this week’s rally helped by the improving trade climate, stronger than expected ISM Non-Manufacturing and a subdued performance in its major counterparts in which EUR/USD and GBP/USD slipped below the 1.1100 and 1.2900 handles respectively. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses traded mixed amid the non-committal risk tone and after an outdated BoJ minutes release failed to spur prices. Elsewhere, AUD/USD and NZD/USD were subdued by the recent broad strength in the greenback and after weaker than expected New Zealand jobs data, while antipodeans also failed to benefit from the recent strength in CNY which breached below the 7.0000 level against USD due to the recent trade optimism and following a firmer than expected reference rate setting.

New Zealand Employment Change (Q3) Q/Q 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.8%). (Newswires) New Zealand Unemployment Rate (Q3) 4.2% vs. Exp. 4.1% (Prev. 3.9%)

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded mostly subdued in which oil gave back some of the prior day’s gains with WTI crude futures pulling back to briefly below the USD 57.00/bbl with pressure seen following a larger than expected build in headline API crude inventories. Gold prices were also lacklustre overnight with the precious metal despondent after its fall from the USD 1500/oz level amid the recent strength in the greenback, while copper mirrored the uninspired trade across the complex and tentative overnight risk tone.

API Crude Inventories: +4.26mln vs. Exp. +1.5mln (Prev. +0.59mln). (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iran's Nuclear Chief Salehi stated Tehran will begin enriching Uranium to 5% at the Fordow plant and that it can enrich uranium to 20% if needed. (Newswires)

 

US

 

The Treasury curve bear-steepened as havens saw outflows with traders noting the positive run of headlines on the US/China trade front, while ISM data also surprised to the upside, resulting in yields rising between 6-7bps across the curve. The Treasury’s 3-year auction was solid, stopping through the screens by 0.1bps, with cover above recent averages; the breakdown showed dealer participation the smallest since August 2017, while direct bidding was in line. T-note futures (Z9) settled 21 ticks lower at 128-29+.

In related news, Democrat candidate Beshear defeated Republican and incumbent Bevin in the Kentucky Gubernatorial Election, while Republican Lieutenant Governor Reeves won the election in Mississippi in what was a fairly tight race against Democrat Attorney General Hood. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded mixed as participants await the next developments in the US-China trade saga
content: Asia equity markets traded lacklustre following a flat finish on Wall St where the major indices remained near record highs on the US-China trade optimism, but with some caution seeping through amid Chinese demands for the removal of tariffs which is seen as a sticking point for the 'phase one' deal. ASX 200 (-0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) were mixed with underperformance in Australia’s gold miners after the precious metal slipped below the psychological key USD 1500/oz level, while trade in Tokyo was stable amid a mixed currency and as the local benchmark took a breather from the prior day’s surge to a fresh yearly high. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) were tentative after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and as participants await the next developments in the trade saga such including whether the US succumbs to China’s demands to roll-back tariffs. Finally, 10yr JGBs declined significantly overnight as the benchmark 10yr JGB yield rose to its highest in around 5 months, while the pressure in JGBs was later exacerbated following mixed 10yr auction results and after prices collapsed through a key support area around 153.60 which previously held up during the last 3 months.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia takes it cue from the flat performance on Wall St with markets awaiting the next developments in the US-China trade saga
content:
Asia equity markets are lacklustre following a flat finish on Wall St where the major indices remained near record highs on the US-China trade optimism, but which some caution seeping through as China is seen to be unwilling to flinch on tariffs and with the removal of levies a sticking point for the 'phase one' deal. ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (Unch.) are relatively indecisive with gold miners underperforming in Australia after the precious metal slipped below the psychological key USD 1500/oz level although downside in the broader market is stemmed by resilience in the energy and financials sectors, while trade in Tokyo is stable amid a mixed currency and as the local benchmark takes a breather from the prior day’s surge to a fresh yearly high. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) are also tentative after the PBoC refrained from open market operations and as participants await the next developments in the trade saga such as if the US succumbs to China’s demands to roll-back tariffs.

In FX markets, the DXY slightly eased back from the 98.00 level although holds on to a majority of the spoils from this week’s rally helped by the improving trade climate, stronger than expected ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI data and a subdued performance in its major counterparts in which EUR/USD and GBP/USD slipped below the 1.1100 and 1.2900 handles respectively. USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are mixed amid the non-committal risk tone and after an outdated BoJ minutes release failed to spur prices. Elsewhere, AUD/USD and NZD/USD are subdued by the recent broad strength in the greenback and after weaker than expected New Zealand jobs data, while antipodeans also failed to benefit from the recent strength in CNY which breached to below the 7.0000 level against USD amid the improving trade environment and following a firmer than expected reference rate setting.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower after similar declines in USTs and with the benchmark 10yr JGB yield at its highest in around 5 months, while a looming 10yr JGB auction has also kept participants sidelined.

Trade

US Senate Finance Committee Director said the Phase One China trade deal will "possibly" be signed in Iowa. (FBN)

Beijing wants Washington to make a solid commitment towards removing tariffs according to sources which added that without this move, a visit to the US by President Xi Jinping would be politically difficult. In related news, reports also suggested that an emboldened China refuses to flinch on tariffs in US trade talks and that a complete removal of levies remains sticking point for 'phase one' deal. (SCMP/Nikkei)

China Global Times Editor tweeted that to reach a deal, China and the US must simultaneously remove the existing additional tariffs at the same ratio and the tariffs to be removed should be in proportion to how much agreement has been reached. The Global Times Editor also tweeted that Beijing will insist that the US proportionally remove existing additional tariffs simultaneously with China, while the editor suggested China will not accept such a phase 1 deal if the US keeps all tariffs and only suspends new tariff threat, in exchange for major concessions. (Twitter)

US imports of Chinese goods subject to tariffs fell by USD 35bln in H1 2019 according to a UN study, which stated that Taiwan, Mexico and the EU are main beneficiaries of the trade war, replacing some Chinese exports to the US. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US remains deeply troubled about reports of detained family members of Uighur Muslim activists. (Newswires)
